review.title: Two forms of minimality in ASPIC+
review.abstract: Many systems of structured argumentation explicitly require that the facts and rules that make up the argument for a conclusion be the minimal set required to derive the conclusion. ASPIC+ does not place such a requirement on arguments, instead requiring that every rule and fact that are part of an argument be used in its construction. Thus ASPIC+ arguments are minimal in the sense that removing any element of the argument would lead to a structure that is not an argument. In this brief note we discuss these two types of minimality and show how the first kind of minimality can, if desired, be recovered in ASPIC+.

sections.text: This is done with the intention that it can be instantiated by a number of concrete systems, which then inherit all the properties of the more abstract system. Aspic "begins with a logical language L with a concept of negation. A given argumentation is then equipped with rules of argumentation, and aspic" distinguishes two types of rules of argumentation: strict rules and defective rules. Strict rules invoked with the help of arguments are rules whose conclusions apply without exception. Defective rules that are denounced are rules whose conclusions apply unless there is an exception. In particular, C is not an argument because the third clause of Definition 4 justifies only the addition of the rules and reasons of an argument for each premise of the rule that is the subject of the clause.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: In this report, we have examined the notion of the minimality of arguments in the context of aspiration. "We have considered two forms of minimality: the first corresponds to the native minimality of aspiration," which implies that arguments do not contain irrelevant reasons or rules. We have found that under the native form of minimality redundant and circular arguments can be gained. Although there is nothing wrong with circular and redundant arguments per se, in some cases it can be helpful to work with arguments that satisfy a stronger form of minimality. A stronger form of minimality is satisfied by what we have identified as regular arguments, as these are the arguments most commonly encountered in argumentation literature. Specifically, regular arguments use a minimal set of arguments and rules to derive their conclusion.
